terms.definition: The science of reciting the Quran correctly, giving each letter its right and dues of characteristics and articulation.
The articulation point — the specific location in the mouth/throat where a letter's sound originates.
Characteristic or attribute of a letter (e.g., heaviness, voicing, softness).
The absence of a vowel on a letter, shown as a small circle (ـْـ) above the letter.
A mark (ـّـ) indicating the letter is doubled/emphasized.
Double vowel marks at the end of nouns (ـًـ ـٍـ ـٌـ) producing an 'n' sound.
A vowel mark (Fathah, Kasrah, or Dammah). Also used as a unit of timing (1 beat).
The short 'a' vowel, shown as a diagonal stroke above a letter (ـَـ).
The short 'i' vowel, shown as a diagonal stroke below a letter (ـِـ).
The short 'u' vowel, shown as a small و above a letter (ـُـ).
A nasal sound resonating from the nasal cavity, lasting 2 beats.
Clear pronunciation — articulating a letter without nasalization or merging.
Merging one letter into the following letter so they become one sound.
Converting the Noon sound into a Meem before the letter Baa.
Hiding or concealing a letter's sound — pronouncing between clarity and merging.
Elongation of a vowel sound using one of three Madd letters (ا و ي).
An echoing/bouncing sound on five specific letters (ق ط ب ج د) when they have sukoon.
Heaviness in pronunciation — the tongue is raised and mouth fills with the sound.
Lightness in pronunciation — the tongue is lowered, producing a thin sound.
Stopping or pausing during recitation, with specific rules for how to end the word.
Continuing recitation without stopping.
An error in recitation. Lahn Jali (clear error) changes meaning. Lahn Khafi (hidden error) affects quality.
A certification given by a qualified teacher confirming a student has mastered Quran recitation with proper Tajweed, tracing back through a chain to the Prophet ﷺ.
A method of recitation attributed to a specific Imam. There are 10 recognized Qira'aat.
The most widely used Qira'ah globally. Hafs ibn Sulayman narrated from his teacher Imam 'Asim ibn Abi An-Najud.
